levels.name: Your first note
levels.dialogue: Someone put my note on the board. But my favourite color is black!
levels.description:
On the left, you see a board. So far, there is only one note pinned on it. Your job is to hang notes on it, or change existing ones, according to people's wishes.

As you can see, Alex wants a note in black. Each note has attributes, such as height, width and background color, as seen in the class 'post-it'.

There is also the class alex. Any changes you declare in that class will only apply to the note that class is attached to.

So now, go ahead and change the attribute background-color of Alex' note to black!

levels.name: Widths and heights
levels.dialogue: I'm not a fan of squares!
levels.description:
Not every element has to fit the predetermined attributes. Feel free to change the height or width of Alex' note!

However, be cautious: every width and height needs a unit. These can be pixels (1px), percent (1%), relative to root font size (1rem), and many others. And don't worry about breaking the website, it will all turn back to normal in the next level.

levels.name: A second note?
levels.dialogue: My cat has gone missing! Please help me put a note about it on the board! It's urgent and requires all attention!
levels.description:
Suddenly, we are in need of a second note. Thus, we need a second div dedicated to Bea. Let us give it the class bea.

Now, we have to set a position. A relative position doesn't change the general layout of the page, while an absolute position places itself according to the parent's position (which in this case is the container of the post-its). Now, how can we force everyone to look at Bea's note first?

Fun fact: every element's default position is static. It is positioned according to the flow.

levels.name: Hide and Seek
levels.dialogue: Someone put this embarassing note on the board! Please make it disappear!
levels.description:
How and if a note is shown is handled by the display attribute. In this chapter, you are introduced to the values inline, block and none.

You will get to know them in detail in the next chapter, so in the meantime, let's make it disappear. As your guess, which one of the display values can make a note go away?

You will find yourself having a hard time overriding the note's default display property (which will be block, since it's a div element), so have to overpower it by attaching !important to your solution. However, in practical use, you should use !important only if nothing else works.

levels.name: Falling in Line
levels.dialogue: I just wanted to say hello and now it's unreadable!
levels.description:
When you look at the HTML code, every lettervis nested in its own p element. Usually p elements (as in 'paragraph') have the default of display: block.

This means that this element will always start a new line and extend to the full width of the note. Now, if you think back, there was a different keyword that makes sure that those elements do not start a new line.

Now, what does that selector mean? That .charlie p? This means that it selects every p element that is inside the element with the charlie class. Selectors with dots before them signify class selectors, while no dot means element selector.
